definition: A type of medication that helps cure bacterial disease by killing infective bacteria inside the body.
The ability of a bacteria to become resistant to the treatment that is being used to kill it, i.e. antibiotics. This provides evidence for evolution.
A form of reproduction that only involves a single parent and creates genetically identical offspring.
An organism that is genetically identical to another and is usually produced by asexual reproduction.
When different organisms compete for the same resources (e.g. food, shelter, and mates) in an ecosystem. It limits population size.
Variation that can take any value between two extremes, e.g. height or weight.
A genetic disorder caused by homozygous recessive alleles which causes mucus build up in the lungs.
Variation that can only take discrete values, e.g. eye color.
Variation in an organism's phenotype due to environmental factors e.g. climate.
A gradual change in the populationâ€™s inherited characteristics over time, by the process of natural selection. This may result in the formation of a new species.
The death of all members of a species. Organisms can become extinct if the process of natural selection is too slow, so the organisms cannot adapt to new environmental conditions.
Sex cells (sperm and egg cells) with half the usual number of chromosomes. They are involved in reproduction.
A section of DNA that codes for a specific amino acid sequence which is polymerized to make a specific protein.
Techniques which are used to correct the defective allele (usually disease causing) in DNA.
The variation in the genes of a species.
The entire genetic material of an organism.
Variation in an organism's phenotype due to genetics because of a variation in alleles.
A form of cell division that produces gametes. They are not genetically identical and contain half the number of chromosomes.
A random change in DNA which increases variation. They may have a neutral, beneficial or damaging effect on the phenotype.
The process by which advantageous alleles are passed down to offspring over many generations, increasing the allele frequency. These alleles give rise to phenotypes best suited to the environment.
A type of chemical that helps control pests by killing them.
The ability of a pest to become resistant to the treatment that is being used to kill it, i.e. pesticide. This provides evidence for evolution.
A consumer that preys on and eats other animals.
A consumer that is eaten by a predator.
Reproduction that involves the fusion of male and female gametes. This method of reproduction produces genetic variation as the offspring are genetically different from the parents.
The differences between individuals of the same species, due to genetics and the environment.
